org.note: One of the publishers of his own `Arminian Bible Christians' Hymnbook'

3 Cable St (1789-99). 7 Brownlow St (1799). Warehouse: Clayton Sq

org.note: Also O'Neill. Succeeded by Francis O'Neal & Sons
On site occupied by Harold Jackson Ltd in 1957. See William Coughtry, William Bateson

Oakes' equipment and presses bought by Samuel Mearne

address.addrLine: Lit St Bartholemew's nr Smithfield. In the Wellyard in Lit St Bartholomew's nr Lame Hospital Gate

org.note: Also Okes. Son of Nicholas Okes. Part father's business c1635; sole manager 1638>. Probably husb Mary Oakes
Also Okes. Widow John Okes. 5 imprints 1643-5. Remarried William Wilson c1645. Wilson assigned copy to Lee
Possibly same as earlier Nicholas Oakes
Partner with her daughter 1802. Probably Pricilla Oakey.
Born Bristol; employed 10 men, 9 boys & 2 girls; brother-in-law George Burrows
Mill formerly held by Elizabeth Rawleigh. Possibly trading as Oakley & Son in 1799. Mill possibly passed to [Mr?] Burt. Held by P Graham by 1813
Possibly Richard Oakley. Mill possibly passed to [Mr?] Burt; held by P Graham by 1813
Born c1748, Hendon, Middlesex. Died at sister's house after vagrant life

address.addrLine: At his hse, Barton St, Westminster

org.note: Songwriter. Aka Oats. His words set to music by Mr T Wright of Devonshire (1748)
Joint guardian w T Smith of Ellin Hudson daughter of & exec Thomas Hudson. Possibly personal link w paper trade
See POPPING, Sarah. Publisher Benjamin Bragg (d.1710)
Editons found in Hove reference library - uncertain whether this magazine/newspaper is local to Hove and/or the Sussex area.
See Ed Blackwell, William Blackwell, Henry Blackwell, John Blackwell
Son of Richard Ockould, bookseller. FSC 1632
Father of Henry Ockould. FSC 1593; Under Warden StatCo 1613. Assoc Joan Broome
Mainperned in case of Hy Hychelle to keep peace
Manchester Unity Order commenced library in May 1849
Trading as William Oddie & Co in 1816
Paid duties at Leeds Collection in 1816
Trading with Samuel Oddy 1805-6; with Samuel Augustus Oddy 1809-10. Bankrupt 1809

Part W Allen & E Wills at Coosebean & Cook's mills until 1791
Aka Offor. Probably related to John Offer
Formerly a bookseller - possibly in London
Associate of John Bill; John Norton sr; Bonham Norton. In 1621 amalgamated with Latin Stock

3 Wheeler pl. Haverstock Hill, Hampstead rd.

Patentee. Daughter of Dr Fulke. Printed father's works by subscription. Assignees included Augustine Mathewes
Printed John Knight, 'A full and particular report of the proceedings of the public meeting held in Manchester on Monday the 18th of January, 1819', 1819.

address.addrLine: In White Fryers, below the Green Dragon Tavern in Fleet St (1670-6)

org.note: Geographer, scholar. Possibly died in 1675. Merchant Taylors' Co. Master of Revels (IE). King's Cosmographer

See David Ogilvy. Succeeded by Ogilvy & Son
Successor to husband Joseph Ogle; part Daniel Smith 1774/1778

address.addrLine: Under the White Swan, nr Kirkgate End (1730) Kirkgate, The Dial (1736). The Dial, at Kirkgate End (1761)

org.note: Succeeded by wid Hannah Ogle 1774 (`Leeds Mercury' 8/4/1740). First librarian of Leeds Library.

Took over as librarian to the Leeds Library on the death of her father, Joseph Ogle - a job she continued until her own death in 1813 when she was succeeded by her daughter, also Mary. 1776 - married bookseller John Robinson

address.addrLine: 5 Great Turnstile, Holborn. 295 Holborn. 37 Paternoster Row

With Thomas Compson leased Hopton Wafers Mill in 1756. Probably left paper making at Hopton Wafers to William Nichols

A hop merch of Bewdley, Worcs who leased Hopton Wafers Mill with Thomas Compson in 1756. Probably left paper making at mill to William Nichols. Sold mill in 1779; mill passed to Thomas Botfield by 1798
Pocket-book seller, general haberdasher and funeral furnisher.

address.addrLine: In Paternoster Row o/a the Black Raven. In Paternoster Row o/a the Checker

org.note: Apprenticed to Thomas Purfoot. FSC 1581. Married widow of George Robinson who succeeded to his bus. March 1588 the Court of Stationers prevented Orwin from printing on his own account ( he had obtained John Kingston's presses by marriage) unless he was formally admitted. Archbishop Whitgift gave permission for Orwin to use presses even though they had been seized by the company (Marprelate complained that Orwin 'wrought popish bookes in corners'), Whitgift then intervened in 1591 to have the presses returned to Orwin.
Mill tenant. Possibly the same as Mr Orray. Possibly tenant of Sir Ralph Hansby's sucrs. Possibly West Mill only

appraiser With Samuel Oxenham & Thomas Eddy successors to Thomas Oxenham. Part Thomas Eddy (1814-17)
With John Thomas Oxenham & Thomas Eddy successors to Thomas Oxenham
